utterances: Whether this will be a big deal or a big dud doesn't matter to Bill Cook(ph).
He's excited.
Cooke is with NASA's Meteoroid Environments Office in Huntsville, Alabama.

To have a meteor shower suddenly appear with rates of tens or hundreds per hour, that's a very rare thing, and it's a unique opportunity both from just going out and looking at it and scientifically because simply by counting meteors, we can tell how active this comet was long before we were born.
And to Alan MacRobert of Sky & Telescope magazine, there's no downside, either.
He says his alarm is already set so he wakes up for the potential show at 3 a.m.
I'm looking for my property on the 2200 block of Raines(ph) off in the lower Ninth Ward and there's so much devastation that I can't even find the property.
John Scully is a New Orleans landlord.
He owned houses all over the city and his houses were destroyed all over the city including several modest two-family homes near a levee break.
They were in the Ninth Ward, a largely black neighborhood down river from the French Quarter.
We visited this devastated area with Scully and two other people with close connections to the neighborhood.
Another is Charese Harrison Nelson(ph), a schoolteacher who is also involved in the African-American parades at Mardi Gras.
She had trouble keeping her composure as she looked at the neighborhood where she grew up.
I don't want to be a pessimist, but golly...
Yeah, I think we will come back.
The man trying to comfort her is Fred Johnson.
He spent two decades helping low-income residents buy their homes, some of which has now been torn off their foundations.

The waters of the Mississippi and Lake Pontchartrain was washed up by the force of God which put everything on the banks of the city and said, `Here are the things that you wouldn't deal with, so deal with them now.'
We brought these three people together as we continue our discussions about the future of New Orleans.
We were in a neighborhood whose destruction led to suggestions that it never be rebuilt.
We stopped near an entire intact roof that was no longer attached to a house.
We found a bit of shade on a street that's caked in dried mud and that's where the teacher, the landlord and the activist talked.
Though she sometimes had to take a break to cry, Charese Harrison Nelson said she is determined to stay.
And I don't call myself an evacuee.
I don't call myself a Katrina survivor.
I call myself a New Orleanian.
I'm not going to abandon the city.
I'm not going to let the city purge me out.
I have property in the Ninth Ward and I'm building a house in the Ninth Ward.
You're going to go ahead with that?
Yes, I am.
Is...
I have to have a place to live.
And my heart is there.
That's where I have to be to be whole.
I can't be whole in Houston, Texas.
Mr.
Scully, how do you feel about rebuilding in this area, someone who owns several properties here?
I wouldn't want to be the first one to do it.
I don't look for this in theory to be built for a while until the levee system gives us the insurance.
And if you rebuild under these conditions, nobody could afford the insurance or they could find insurance.
So right now even in areas of the city that haven't been affected in the Kenner, Metairie area, it's very difficult to find insurance companies that are going to write policies.
Even in the areas that were not as hard hit, it's hard to find insurance at this moment?
Yeah, because of the fact is that the insurance companies are taking a big hit on other areas of the city.

They have the bottom line on it because nothing will get accomplished, nothing will be built, nothing will be sold unless the insurance companies are going to be backing the homeowners or the investment owners.
What insurance company is going to step up to the plate and start insuring people right away without rebuilding the levee system?

When we look around this neighborhood which is near the levee breach where most of the houses are just piles of wood now--we're looking at appliances and cars that floated into the yards of houses that no longer exist, trees snapped in half--where do you start in a situation like this?
Because of the hurricane, I guess you have to literally start on the ground, from the bottom.
I mean, there's not much that's salvageable here.
I don't see anything.
Maybe, you know, the trees.
Does this destruction raise the question for any of you as to whether these lower areas of the city should be rebuilt at all?
When I look at this, I'm concerned about my database of 2,500 homeowners.
Twenty-five hundred that you've helped over the last 20 years.
Over the last 20 years, and then I have a client who just bought a house right up the street on Flood Street, single-family mom, three children.
She just got wiped out.

New Orleanians and no other city cannot have a city where you have all upper income people and no lower income people, and New Orleans has a history, if you know anything about New Orleans, poor and rich have always lived together.
The haves and have nots have always lived together.
Now I don't mean under the same roof, but two blocks away, three blocks away.
The master's house and the slave house was always very close if you wanted to take it from that aspect.
My position on this is, is that what happens--New Orleans has become the classroom for what's wrong in urban America.
And if you want to know what's wrong in urban America, look into this classroom.
Charese Harrison Nelson, what has to happen for the city to recover culturally?
We can't rely on the city to do that.
We're going to have to go into our neighborhoods--well, not really go into our neighborhoods but start the networking.
And the way we do it is the way we do it in the neighborhoods.
You have a number, I have a number and we start connecting the dots.
And that's what I've been doing.
I've just...
You've been calling across the country.
I've been calling across the country and every day...
Even though the neighborhood is 2,000 miles across or more.
Right.
Rats need a keen sense of smell to survive.
But why would humans send a river of new brain cells to a place that sorts garlic from oregano?
Faull thinks the answer is that most of the new cells are diverted before they reach the human smell center.

You know, we were speaking to a member of the state board of education this week who said, `Given the way that New Orleans has treated its poor, especially in terms of education, it could very well be that a lot of people are better off where they've evacuated to.'
It's not going to be better.
What you'll have is something different.
We will probably make something different.
Like you have a little Italy and a little China, you're probably going to have little New Orleans in places.
And anybody...
Right.
Fred, you know I'm not--you...
If I can just take it back on that.
We all are going to be cautious and careful about the new New Orleans.
Who does it include and who does it omit?
Myself, I'm not participating in the fear factor because there's a serious fear factor going.
Well, what's going to happen?
Well, where are we going to live?
Are we coming back?
I'm a New Orleanians, born and raised here, and when they put me down, they're going to put me down here and they're going to put me down with a brass band.
You intend to be buried here with a jazz funeral.
I intend to.
When our conversation was over, housing activist Fred Johnson returned to the latest in his string of temporary homes in Jackson, Mississippi.
Landlord John Scully returned to his undamaged home here in New Orleans.
Teacher Charese Harrison Nelson went to start cleaning up her mother's ruined house in the Ninth Ward and then began a six-hour drive back to Houston.
For now, she says, it's the closest place she can find to rest her head after visiting the city where she once lived.
This is NPR News.
Now, a story from the Netherlands.
A short film that hasn't even been released yet is causing a lot of commotion in that country and in the Islamic world.
Its creator is an extreme right-wing, anti-Islam member of the Dutch Parliament.
Geert Wilders says his film will unveil the Koran as a how-to guide for committing terrorist attacks and other violence.
Gregory Crouch reports from the Dutch town of Venlo.
Geert Wilders courts controversy.
His party captured six percent of the Dutch vote with promises to ban the Koran and to stop all immigration from Muslim countries.
His supporters argue he protects traditional Dutch values.
His critics say he exacerbates religious tensions.
A prominent trade union leader called Wilders simply evil — a claim he rejects.
Of course I am not evil.
Do I look evil to you?
Maybe I do, but I'm not.
The Netherlands is on edge.
Few people know for sure what's in Wilders' anti-Koran film but some fear the worst.
Iran wants the film banned.
The Taliban is threatening Dutch soldiers in Afghanistan.
And Pakistan tried to block YouTube before the film's release.
In light of all of this, Dutch Foreign Minister Maxime Verhagen was blunt.
(Through translator) I find it irresponsible to broadcast this film.
That's because Dutch companies, Dutch soldiers and Dutch residents abroad could and will be in danger.

But the foreign minister's statement raised new concerns that Dutch politicians are caving in the threats from fundamentalist Muslims, or, put more strongly, capitulating — a loaded term, given the Dutch surrender to the Nazis.
